note_content.Chief Complaint: Concerns about increasing number of moles and recent changes in their appearance.
note_content.History of Present Illness: Patient noticed several new moles over the past 6 months that have been changing in color and size. Not associated with pain or bleeding.
note_content.Past Medical History: Hypertension, controlled with medication; no previous skin issues.
note_content.Family History: Mother had melanoma, diagnosed at age 65.
note_content.Social History: Non-smoker, consumes alcohol socially, works as a construction manager, often exposed to sun.
note_content.Review of Systems: No weight loss, fever, or fatigue. No new rashes or itching, aside from the areas around the new moles.
note_content.Vital Signs: Blood pressure stable at 130/85, normal heart rate, temperature, and respiratory rate.
note_content.Physical Examination: New moles noted on upper back and shoulders, varying from tan to dark brown, some with irregular borders, ranging from 2-6mm. No signs of infection or ulceration.
note_content.Investigations: Biopsy of two most suspicious moles recommended.

Assessment and Plan.Problem List: Atypical moles with potential for melanoma.
Assessment and Plan.Differential Diagnosis: Dysplastic nevus, benign nevocellular nevus, melanoma.
Plan: Scheduled skin biopsy of questionable moles.
Follow-up appointment for biopsy results and further evaluation in 2 weeks.
Patient education on skin cancer awareness and sun protection advised.
Monitor blood pressure and continue current antihypertensive regimen.
